DataElement.preferredName: Breast Carcinoma Adjuvant Radiation Therapy Receive Type
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The type of adjuvant radiation therapy received for breast carcinoma.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Breast Carcinoma Adjuvant Radiation Therapy Receive
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A carcinoma arising from the breast, most commonly the terminal ductal-lobular unit. It is the most common malignant tumor in females. Risk factors include country of birth, family history, menstrual and reproductive history, fibrocystic disease and epithelial hyperplasia, exogenous estrogens, contraceptive agents, and ionizing radiation. The vast majority of breast carcinomas are adenocarcinomas (ductal or lobular). Breast carcinoma spreads by direct invasion, by the lymphatic route, and by the blood vessel route. The most common site of lymph node involvement is the axilla._Radiation therapy that is administered subsequent to the main treatment plan to minimize or prevent disease recurrence._To take, accept, or get something offered.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A carcinoma arising from the breast, most commonly the terminal ductal-lobular unit.  Breast carcinoma may affect both females and males.  It is the most common malignant tumor and the leading cause of carcinoma death in women.  Risk factors include country of birth, family history, menstrual and reproductive history, fibrocystic disease and epithelial hyperplasia, exogenous estrogens, contraceptive agents, and ionizing radiation.  The widespread use of mammography has contributed in the detection of very early cancerous lesions (less than 2mm in diameter).  The vast majority of breast carcinomas are adenocarcinomas (ductal or lobular).  Breast carcinoma spreads by direct invasion, by the lymphatic route, and by the blood vessel route.  The most common site of lymph node involvment is the axilla.  Breast carcinomas infrequently occur in males (particularly elderly individuals and patients with Klinefelter's syndrome).  The therapy of breat carcinoma includes surgery, radiation therapy, hormonal therapy and chemotherapy, depending on the type and extend of the disease. --2002

Concepts.definition: A carcinoma arising from the breast, most commonly the terminal ductal-lobular unit. It is the most common malignant tumor in females. Risk factors include country of birth, family history, menstrual and reproductive history, fibrocystic disease and epithelial hyperplasia, exogenous estrogens, contraceptive agents, and ionizing radiation. The vast majority of breast carcinomas are adenocarcinomas (ductal or lobular). Breast carcinoma spreads by direct invasion, by the lymphatic route, and by the blood vessel route. The most common site of lymph node involvement is the axilla.

Property.preferredDefinition: Radiation therapy that is administered subsequent to the main treatment plan to minimize or prevent disease recurrence.:To take, accept, or get something offered.

Concepts.definition: Radiation therapy that is administered subsequent to the main treatment plan to minimize or prevent disease recurrence.
To take, accept, or get something offered.

ValueDomain.preferredName: Breast Carcinoma Adjuvant Radiation Therapy Type
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: The type of adjuvant radiation therapy for breast carcinoma.

PermissibleValues.value: Post breast conserving surgery radiation Â– breast, supraclavicular nodes, internal mammary nodes, and undissected axilla
PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Post Breast Conservation Treatment Radiation Therapy Breast Supraclavicular Lymph Node Internal Mammary Lymph Node And Negation Dissection Axillary Lymph Node

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Post Breast Conservation Treatment Radiation Therapy Breast Supraclavicular Lymph Node Internal Mammary Lymph Node And Negation Dissection Axillary Lymph Node
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Happening at a time subsequent to a reference time; later in time or order.: Breast conservation treatment is defined as excision of the primary tumor and adjacent breast tissue, followed by radiation therapy.  This procedure is also referred to as lumpectomy, segmental mastectomy, or partial mastectomy. (from Consensus Statements: Treatment of Early-stage Breast Cancer, 1990): Treatment of a disease by means of exposure of the target or the whole body to radiation. Radiation therapy is often used as part of curative therapy and occasionally as a component of palliative treatment for cancer. Other uses include total body irradiation prior to transplantation.: One of two hemispheric projections of variable size situated in the subcutaneous layer over the pectoralis major muscle on either side of the chest.: A lymph node which is located above the clavicle.: Any of the lymph nodes of the breast located under the ribcage, near the sternum.: An article which expresses the relation of connection or addition. It is used to conjoin a word with a word, a clause with a clause, or a sentence with a sentence.: An operation in which a term denies or inverts the meaning of another term or construction.: The process of cutting apart or separating tissue as, for example, in the study of anatomy or in the course of a surgical procedure.: One of approximately 20-30 lymph nodes in chain formation that traverse the concavity of the underarm to the clavicle.

Concepts.definition: Happening at a time subsequent to a reference time; later in time or order.

Breast conservation treatment is defined as excision of the primary tumor and adjacent breast tissue, followed by radiation therapy.  This procedure is also referred to as lumpectomy, segmental mastectomy, or partial mastectomy. (from Consensus Statements: Treatment of Early-stage Breast Cancer, 1990)

Treatment of a disease by means of exposure of the target or the whole body to radiation. Radiation therapy is often used as part of curative therapy and occasionally as a component of palliative treatment for cancer. Other uses include total body irradiation prior to transplantation.
One of two hemispheric projections of variable size situated in the subcutaneous layer over the pectoralis major muscle on either side of the chest.
A lymph node which is located above the clavicle.
Any of the lymph nodes of the breast located under the ribcage, near the sternum.
An article which expresses the relation of connection or addition. It is used to conjoin a word with a word, a clause with a clause, or a sentence with a sentence.
An operation in which a term denies or inverts the meaning of another term or construction.
The process of cutting apart or separating tissue as, for example, in the study of anatomy or in the course of a surgical procedure.
One of approximately 20-30 lymph nodes in chain formation that traverse the concavity of the underarm to the clavicle.
